newsitem.title: USA: Catholic school debt issue passes Chicago council.
newsitem.headline: Catholic school debt issue passes Chicago council.

text.p: A $7 million conduit debt issue for a Catholic high school sailed through the Chicago City Council Wednesday on a 42 to 2 vote.
But the issue may still face a challenge from the Chicago office of the American Civil Liberties Union.

The tax-exempt, variable-rate note deal for De La Salle High School on Chicago's south side was the first conduit financing approved by the city for a religious-based school. The notes will be backed by a letter of credit from Northern Trust Bank and sold through George K. Baum & Co.
Valerie Phillips, public information director for the ACLU, said the group was concerned the issue will violate constitutional principles governing the separation of church and state.
"It has the potential of putting the city in the position of sponsoring and endorsing religious education," she said.
Phillips added that the ACLU needed to review the debt financing and construction plans for the high school before deciding its next move.

Proceeds from the deal would be used to build a sports center and for other improvements, according to Anthony Fratto, a senior vice president at George K. Baum. He has also said the school plans to use pledged funds and grants to pay off the notes.
Fratto and city officials have pointed out that the Illinois Development Finance Authority has issued tax-exempt bonds in the past for religious-based schools on a conduit basis.
According to the state authority, more than $38 million of bonds have been sold for three religious-based high schools.
